questions.text: A 30-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of a painful rash for the past 2 days. The rash initially appeared on his left lower abdomen and has spread to the rest of the abdomen and left upper thigh over the last 24 hours. The pain is exacerbated with movement. He initially thought the skin rash was an allergic reaction to a new laundry detergent, but it did not respond to over-the-counter antihistamines. Six weeks ago, the patient was diagnosed with Hodgkin lymphoma and was started on doxorubicin, bleomycin, vinblastine, and dacarbazine. He is sexually active with one female partner and uses condoms for contraception. The patient appears pale. His temperature is 37.9°C (100.2°F), pulse is 80/min, and blood pressure is 117/72 mm Hg. Examination shows two markedly enlarged cervical lymph nodes. A photograph of the rash is shown. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Outpatient treatment with oral penicillin V

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Oral penicillin can be effective against erysipelas in immunocompetent individuals who do not have a severe infection. Erysipelas can manifest as a painful, well-demarcated rash involving large areas of the body in immunosuppressed patients. It does not usually manifest as a vesicular rash. Additionally, in immunosuppressed patients, inpatient treatment and parenteral antibiotics would be preferred.

B) INCORRECT:

Topical permethrin is used to treat scabies and lice. Scabies can cause a similar disseminated rash in immunosuppressed patients. However, it is usually pruritic and not primarily painful or multivesicular. Additionally, an immunosuppressed patient should receive inpatient treatment.

C) CORRECT:

Acyclovir is an antiviral medication used to treat herpes simplex or varicella zoster infections. Immunocompromise secondary to chemotherapy can lead to dissemination of herpes zoster. Both immunocompromise and a disseminated rash are indications for inpatient treatment. Dissemination is present if there are > 20 extradermatomal lesions, involvement of ≥ 3 dermatomes, and/or visceral organ involvement. Antiviral therapy should be initiated as early as possible since the effectiveness of antiviral treatment decreases as the disease progresses. It speeds up the resolution of lesions, reduces viral shedding, reduces the formation of new lesions, decreases pain, and reduces the risk of postherpetic neuralgia.

D) INCORRECT:

Valacyclovir is an antiviral drug effective against herpes simplex and herpes zoster viruses. Oral valacyclovir is used in immunocompetent individuals within 72 hours of the onset of lesions, but another regimen is indicated in immunosuppressed patients such as this one.

E) INCORRECT:

Ceftriaxone can be used to treat severe erysipelas and cellulitis in immunocompromised patients. Both these conditions are commonly caused by group A hemolytic streptococci. Erysipelas can manifest as a painful, well-demarcated rash involving large areas of the body in immunosuppressed patients. It does not usually manifest as a vesicular rash.
questions.hint: A multivesicular rash on an erythematous base in this immunocompromised patient is indicative of herpes zoster.

questions.text:
Treatment with intravenous acyclovir is initiated. Three days later, the patient develops progressively worse fatigue, headache, and colicky pain in his right flank. His temperature is 36.7°C (98°F), pulse is 85/min, and blood pressure is 135/80 mm Hg. Examination shows no new lesions. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
11.3 g/dL


Serum



 Na+

140 mEq/L


 Cl-

99 mEq/L


 K+

5.5 mEq/L


 HCO3-

22 mEq/L


 Urea nitrogen

56 mg/dL


 Creatinine

3.2 mg/dL


Which of the following is the most likely finding on urinalysis?

choices.text: Gram-negative rods and white blood cell casts
Red blood cell casts and acanthocytes
Intact red blood cells and blood clots

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Eosinophils and RBCs are findings that suggest allergic interstitial nephritis (AIN), a type of nephropathy that occurs following the intake of certain drugs and can manifest with flank pain. However, AIN typically manifests with a diffuse maculopapular rash. Furthermore, this condition is caused by a hypersensitivity reaction to drugs such as antibiotics, NSAIDs, and diuretics; acyclovir is not a common cause.

B) INCORRECT:

Gram-negative rods and WBC casts indicate pyelonephritis, which can cause colicky flank pain, fatigue, and headaches. However, a patient with pyelonephritis would have fever/chills and often nausea, vomiting, and dysuria.

C) INCORRECT:

RBC casts and acanthocytes are findings consistent with nephritic syndrome. Although nephritic syndrome can cause alteration in renal function parameters such as creatinine and BUN, this condition does not commonly cause flank pain. Patients would also typically have signs of at least mild edema (e.g., periorbital). Furthermore, acyclovir treatment is not associated with nephritic syndrome.

D) INCORRECT:

Intact RBCs and blood clots suggest renal trauma. However, there is no history of trauma and the patient most likely has a condition related to her acyclovir treatment.

E) CORRECT:

Crystals and white blood cells are findings consistent with crystal-induced acute kidney injury (AKI), which is consistent with this patient's colicky pain, increasing fatigue, headaches, and increased levels of BUN and creatinine following acyclovir treatment. Poorly soluble drugs such as acyclovir may form crystals that precipitate inside the renal tubules, leading to tubular obstruction and toxicity that causes kidney damage. Adequate volume repletion before and during administration of acyclovir is effective in preventing crystal-induced AKI.

F) INCORRECT:

Fatty casts and proteinuria indicate nephrotic syndrome. Although some drugs (e.g., penicillamine, NSAIDs) can cause nephrotic syndrome, acyclovir does not. Moreover, a patient with nephrotic syndrome would present with marked edema (initially periorbital, then pitting edema in other areas).
questions.hint: Drugs with low urine solubility such as acyclovir can precipitate in the renal tubules.

questions.text:
A 63-year-old man comes to the physician because of generalized fatigue and malaise for 2 months. He has been unable to engage in his daily activities. Three months ago, he was treated for a urinary tract infection with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. He has hypertension, asthma, and chronic lower back pain. Current medications include hydrochlorothiazide, an albuterol inhaler, naproxen, and an aspirin-caffeine combination. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows conjunctival pallor. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
9.1 g/dL


Leukocyte count
8,900/mm3



Erythrocyte sedimentation rate
13 mm/h


Serum



 Na+

136 mEq/L


 K+

4.8 mEq/L


 Cl-

102 mEq/L


 Urea nitrogen
41 mg/dL


 Glucose
70 mg/dL


 Creatinine
2.4 mg/dL


 Calcium
9.8 mg/dL


Urine



 Protein
1+


 Blood
1+


 RBCs
none


 WBCs
8–9/hpf


 Bacteria
none


Urine cultures are negative. Ultrasound shows shrunken kidneys with irregular contours and papillary calcifications. Which of the following is the most likely underlying mechanism of this patient's renal failure?

choices.text: Excess amount of light chain production
Precipitation of drugs within the renal tubules

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Infection with an acid-fast bacillus such as M. tuberculosis can cause renal damage and subsequent chronic kidney disease. However, this patient does not have risk factors for tuberculosis (e.g., travel to areas where the disease is endemic, HIV, time spent in prison) or symptoms suggestive of the disease (e.g., hemoptysis, night sweats, weight loss).

B) CORRECT:

Prostacyclins enhance renal blood flow by dilating renal capillaries, most prominently in the medulla of the kidney. By inhibiting prostacyclin production, nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) decrease renal blood flow. After prolonged exposure to analgesics, especially analgesics used in combination, patients develop renal papillary necrosis and subsequent analgesic nephropathy (chronic kidney disease). The association between NSAIDs and chronic kidney disease (CKD) is especially strong in patients using a combination of NSAIDs, such as this patient. No single NSAID that is currently used is definitively associated with the development of CKD. The combination of aspirin and caffeine is not more dangerous to the kidneys than other NSAIDs, but patients might use the combination drug longer than they otherwise would if they become dependent on the caffeine.

C) INCORRECT:

Excessive light chain production is most frequently associated with multiple myeloma and systemic amyloidosis and can cause chronic kidney disease (CKD). Patients with multiple myeloma present with elevated serum calcium, pain related to skeletal disease involvement, and anemia. This patient has normal serum calcium levels. The chronic lower back pain in this patient is of too long a course for it to be attributable to multiple myeloma and his anemia is likely due to chronic kidney disease. In addition to renal disease, systemic amyloidosis manifests with involvement of multiple organ systems, including the cardiovascular system (cardiomyopathy), skin (waxy skin and easy bruising), hepatic system (hepatomegaly), and nervous system (peripheral neuropathy). This patient does not show involvement of any of these organ systems. Additionally, the kidney disease seen with systemic amyloidosis usually manifests with more severe proteinuria than that seen in this patient.

In addition to renal disease, systemic amyloidosis manifests with involvement of multiple organ systems, including the cardiovascular system (cardiomyopathy), skin (waxy skin and easy bruising), hepatic system (hepatomegaly), and nervous system (peripheral neuropathy). This patient does not show involvement of any of these organ systems. Additionally, the kidney disease seen with systemic amyloidosis usually manifests with more severe proteinuria than that seen in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

Drugs such as acyclovir, indinavir, methotrexate, and ciprofloxacin are poorly soluble in urine and can precipitate in renal tubules, building up as crystals that cause acute kidney injury (AKI) within one week after administration of the offending drug. This patient has been symptomatic for 2 months and has not been exposed to any drugs that commonly cause crystal-induced AKI (e.g., acyclovir, ciprofloxacin, methotrexate) making another diagnosis more likely.

E) INCORRECT:

MUC1 is one of the genes associated with autosomal dominant tubulointerstitial kidney disease (medullary cystic kidney disease), an extremely rare disease. Patients with this disease almost always have a strong family history of kidney disease, which this patient does not have. Ultrasound findings sometimes, but not always, reveal cysts within the renal medulla. This patient has neither evidence of cystic kidneys nor a history suggestive of the disease.

F) INCORRECT:

A hypersensitivity reaction to NSAIDs or a sulfonamide antibiotic, such as trimethoprim/sulfamethoxazole, can cause acute kidney injury in the form of tubulointerstitial nephritis, which would manifest as a rapid decompensation in kidney function. Potential symptoms and findings include fever, rash, and eosinophilia. This patient does not have any of these signs and his two-month history of fatigue suggests a more chronic disease course.
questions.hint: This patient's fatigue, anemia, uremia, elevated creatinine, hematuria, proteinuria, sterile pyuria, and shrunken kidneys with calcifications on ultrasound indicate chronic kidney disease. His long-term use of nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) makes analgesic nephropathy the most likely diagnosis.

questions.text:
A 63-year-old man comes to the physician because of fever for 3 days. During this period, he has had fatigue, increased urinary frequency, and severe burning with urination. The patient reports that his urine is red and has a strange odor. He has taken acetaminophen twice a day for the past two days with no improvement in his symptoms. He has type 2 diabetes mellitus. His only medication is metformin. He appears uncomfortable. His temperature is 39.0°C (102.2°F). Examination shows right-sided costovertebral angle tenderness. Laboratory studies show a leukocyte count of 16,000/mm3 and an erythrocyte sedimentation rate of 40 mm/hr. Urine dipstick shows leukocyte esterase and nitrites. Urinalysis shows:


Blood
2+


Protein
2+


WBC
24/hpf


RBC
50/hpf


RBC casts
none


WBC casts
numerous


Granular casts
none


Results of initial urine cultures are pending. Damage to which of the following structures is the most likely cause of this patient's hematuria?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Acute PN causes edema and neutrophilic inflammation of the renal tubules, which can result in tubular destruction. Gross hematuria originating from the renal tubules, however, is not an expected feature of PN. Instead, tubular inflammation in PN leads to the formation of parenchymal microabscesses while glomeruli and blood vessels are spared. Luminal granulocytes form WBC casts, which then become visible on urinalysis, as seen here. Although the complication seen in this patient with PN can also affect the renal tubules, they are not the main source of hematuria in this condition. Moreover, granular casts on urinalysis are a characteristic feature of acute tubular necrosis, which is not usually caused by PN.

B) CORRECT:

The renal papilla, located in the medulla, is the area where the renal pyramids, formed by the collecting ducts, connect with the minor calyces. Renal papillary necrosis (RPN) is a potentially life-threatening complication of severe PN, which is caused by ascending bacterial infections of the bladder with organisms such as Escherichia coli and other enteric flora. RPN can result from any condition associated with ischemia; more than 50% of patients with RPN have more than one underlying cause, which is also the case here. This patient has type 2 diabetes mellitus and PN, both of which can lead to RPN independently. If these conditions are concurrent, type 2 diabetes mellitus is a risk factor for the progression of PN to RPN. The most common urinalysis findings for RPN include gross hematuria without RBC casts, proteinuria, and pyuria, all of which are seen here.

Acute PN causes purulent inflammation of the interstitium resulting in the destruction of the renal parenchyma, the renal tubules, and, in some cases, the renal pelvis. Hematuria may be seen in PN without other complications but would be rather microscopic than macroscopic in these cases.

C) INCORRECT:

Urinary tract infections involving the urethral epithelium manifest with urinary frequency and dysuria. However, systemic manifestations such as fever, flank pain, proteinuria, and hematuria are usually not present.

D) INCORRECT:

Damage to the renal glomerular basement membrane is most commonly caused by autoimmune diseases such as Goodpasture syndrome. Although urinalysis often shows proteinuria, pyuria, and hematuria, the absence of dysmorphic RBCs, RBC casts, and granular casts makes this option unlikely. Moreover, Goodpasture syndrome would not explain the presence of fever and leukocytosis.

E) INCORRECT:

Bleeding of the bladder mucosa may result from acute cystitis and/or malignancy. Although elevated WBCs on urinalysis are commonly seen in acute cystitis and gross hematuria can be due to hemorrhagic cystitis in women, flank pain and WBC casts are uncommon and suggest infection of the renal pelvis rather than the bladder. Gross hematuria in men should prompt further workup for urothelial malignancy, which can manifest with painless hematuria, irritative voiding symptoms (dysuria, urinary frequency, urgency), and, if the renal pelvis is obstructed, flank pain. Pyuria or proteinuria, however, is not expected in urothelial cancer. This patient's gross hematuria is most likely caused by a complication of PN for which type 2 diabetes mellitus is a predisposing factor.
questions.hint: The combination of fever, leukocytosis, urinary symptoms (e.g., urinary frequency, dysuria), and costovertebral angle tenderness in a male patient with type 2 diabetes mellitus aged > 60 years is consistent with complicated pyelonephritis (PN). This patient has developed a complication of PN that characteristically manifests with gross hematuria (urine with red streaks) without RBC casts.

questions.text:
A 57-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of pain in the sides of his abdomen and blood-tinged urine since the previous night. Over the last 2 days, he has also had progressive malaise, myalgia, and a generalized itchy rash. He has a history of gastroesophageal reflux that did not respond to ranitidine but has improved since taking pantoprazole 2 months ago. He occasionally takes acetaminophen for back pain. His vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows a generalized, diffuse maculopapular rash. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
13 g/dL


Leukocyte count
7,800/mm3



Serum



 Na+

140 mEq/L


 Cl-

105 mEq/L


 K+

4.6 mEq/L


 HCO3-

25 mEq/L


 Glucose
92 mg/dL


 Creatinine


4.1 mg/dL


Renal ultrasonography shows no abnormalities. Which of the following findings is most likely to be observed in this patient?

choices.text: Elevated levels of eosinophils in urine
Dermal IgA deposition on skin biopsy
Mesangial IgA deposits on renal biopsy

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Eosinophiluria is a typical finding in patients with allergic interstitial nephritis, a form of acute tubulointerstitial nephritis. This condition is typically caused by a hypersensitivity reaction to drugs, especially PPIs, NSAIDs, antibiotics, and diuretics. The onset of symptoms is variable (commonly 2–3 months following the exposure) and usually does not depend on the drug dose. The first step in the management of this patient should be to discontinue PPIs and administer IV fluids.

Further common findings in allergic interstitial nephritis include microscopic hematuria as well as elevated serum creatinine and eosinophilia.

B) INCORRECT:

Dermal IgA deposition on skin biopsy is a typical finding in patients with Henoch-Schönlein purpura (HSP), a type of small vessel vasculitis that manifests with a skin rash with palpable purpura in almost all patients. However, most cases (90%) occur in children < 10 years old, and about half of individuals with HSP present with features of nephritic syndrome (e.g., edema, oliguria, and hypertension), which this patient does not have.

C) INCORRECT:

Positive nitrites on dipstick test are a typical finding in patients with urinary tract infections, which in combination with flank pain, hematuria, and myalgia, could indicate pyelonephritis. However, this patient lacks other typical features of pyelonephritis including fever, dysuria, and costovertebral angle tenderness. Moreover, his other findings, including diffuse maculopapular rash in conjunction with a history of taking PPIs, make a different finding more likely.

D) INCORRECT:

Papillary calcifications on CT imaging are a typical finding in patients with analgesic nephropathy. This patient has a history of taking acetaminophen, which is associated with analgesic nephropathy. He also presents with some clinical findings of analgesic nephropathy including hematuria and elevated creatinine levels. However, renal sonography of patients with analgesic nephropathy would typically show shrunken kidneys and papillary calcifications, which is not the case here. Moreover, his other findings, including flank pain and diffuse maculopapular rash in conjunction with a history of taking PPIs, make a different finding more likely.

E) INCORRECT:

Urinary crystals on brightfield microscopy are a typical finding in patients with crystal-induced acute kidney injury (AKI). Drugs with low urine solubility (e.g., acyclovir, indinavir, ciprofloxacin, and methotrexate) precipitate in the renal tubules and can thus cause tubular obstruction leading to crystal-induced AKI. Crystal-induced AKI is often detected by increased creatinine levels and some cases may manifest with hematuria and flank pain, as seen in this patient. However, most individuals with crystal-induced AKI are asymptomatic and this patient lacks a history of taking drugs associated with the condition.

F) INCORRECT:

Mesangial IgA deposits on renal biopsy are a characteristic finding in patients with IgA nephropathy (Berger's disease). This patient has some features of IgA nephropathy, including gross hematuria and flank pain. However, IgA nephropathy mostly occurs in patients at 20–30 years of age, is usually triggered by upper respiratory tract or gastrointestinal infections, and does not cause a maculopapular rash. Moreover, this patient lacks other typical findings of IgA nephropathy, such as low-grade fever and hypertension.

G) INCORRECT:

Crescent-shape extracapillary cell proliferation is a typical finding in patients with rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (RPGN). This patient has some features of RPGN, including gross hematuria, flank pain and a marked increase in creatinine (often > 3 mg/dL). However, RPGN would not explain the maculopapular rash and is not associated with PPIs. Finally, RPGN typically manifests with elevated inflammatory markers (e.g., leukocytosis) and decreased urine output or anuria.
questions.hint: Hematuria, a maculopapular rash, flank pain, along with increased creatinine levels 2 months after starting treatment with proton pump inhibitor (PPI) suggests allergic interstitial nephritis.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old woman comes to the physician because of flank pain and myalgia for the past 2 days. One week ago, she had a fever and a sore throat and was prescribed antibiotics. She is otherwise healthy and has no history of serious illness. Her temperature is 37.9°C (100.2°F), pulse is 70/min, and blood pressure is 128/75 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a soft abdomen and no costovertebral angle tenderness. Examination of the mouth and pharynx shows no abnormalities. There is a faint maculopapular rash over the trunk and extremities. Serum creatinine is 2.4 mg/dL. Urinalysis shows:


Protein
2+


Blood
2+


RBC
20–30/hpf


WBC
12/hpf


Bacteria
none


Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Allergic interstitial nephritis is a form of acute tubulointerstitial nephritis that is typically caused by a hypersensitivity reaction to drugs, including antibiotics. Fever, rash, and eosinophilia are typical manifestations of allergic interstitial nephritis, but all three findings are rarely seen together. Symptom onset can occur from days to weeks following exposure and usually does not depend on the drug dose. The first step in the management of this patient's allergic interstitial nephritis is discontinuation of penicillin (if she is still taking it) and administration of IV fluids.

B) INCORRECT:

Henoch-Schönlein purpura (HSP) is a type of small vessel vasculitis that typically manifests with hematuria, exanthem with palpable purpura, and abdominal pain. HSP most commonly occurs in children (90% of cases in children < 10 years). Also, about half of individuals with HSP present with features of nephritic syndrome (e.g., edema, oliguria and hypertension), which this patient lacks.

C) INCORRECT:

Pyelonephritis can manifest with acute flank pain, hematuria, and myalgia. However, this patient lacks other typical features of pyelonephritis, including fever, dysuria, costovertebral angle tenderness, and bacteriuria on urinalysis. In addition, her diffuse maculopapular rash and history of recent antibiotic use make a different diagnosis more likely.

D) INCORRECT:

Drugs with low urine solubility (e.g., acyclovir, indinavir, ciprofloxacin, and methotrexate) can precipitate within the renal tubules and cause tubular obstruction, leading to crystal-induced acute kidney injury. Crystal-induced AKI is often detected through increased creatinine levels, and in some cases, may manifest with hematuria and flank pain. However, most individuals with crystal-induced AKI are asymptomatic. Also, this patient has no history of taking drugs associated with crystal-induced AKI.

E) INCORRECT:

While eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis causes glomerulonephritis that results in hematuria and increased creatinine, the most common symptoms are severe allergic asthma attacks and a rash with nodules and palpable purpura, which are absent in this patient.

F) INCORRECT:

Acute tubular necrosis (ATN) is caused by either an ischemic or toxic insult. The presentation of ATN varies widely, although most patients have a history of nephrotoxic drug use (e.g., aminoglycosides or sulfonamide antibiotics). ATN does not cause rash, nor is it associated with penicillin antibiotics, which this patient presumably took.

G) INCORRECT:

Poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN) can manifest with flank pain, elevated creatinine levels, and nephritic sediment 1–6 weeks after acute tonsillitis. However, PSGN does not manifest with a maculopapular rash. Additionally, this patient does not present with the most common features of PSGN, such as prominent facial edema, hypertension, and gross hematuria.

H) INCORRECT:

Although thin basement membrane disease is typically asymptomatic, episodes of hematuria, proteinuria, and flank pain can occur after an upper respiratory infection. Thin basement membrane disease does not cause rash.
questions.hint: This patient most likely had acute tonsillitis caused by group A streptococcal infection that was treated with penicillin. One week after beginning antibiotic treatment, she presents with flank pain, a rash, impaired renal function (elevated creatinine levels), microscopic hematuria, and sterile pyuria.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman with poorly controlled type 2 diabetes mellitus comes to the emergency department because of a 5-day history of a severely painful, blistering rash. The rash began over the right forehead, and spread to the chest, back, and bilateral upper extremities over the next 2 days. She is diagnosed with disseminated cutaneous herpes zoster and hospitalized for antiviral therapy. Prior to admission, her only medication was insulin. On the second day of her stay, she develops bilateral episodic, cramping flank pain and nausea. Her temperature is 36.7°C (98°F), pulse is 80/min, and blood pressure is 128/76 mm Hg. Examination shows a healing rash over the forehead, chest, and extremities, with no evidence of new blisters. Her serum blood urea nitrogen is 33 mg/dL and serum creatinine is 3.5 mg/dL. On admission, her serum urea nitrogen was 18 mg/dL and her serum creatinine was 1.1 mg/dL. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's laboratory findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Glomerular basement membrane glycosylation is one of the mechanisms by which diabetes damages the glomeruli and causes diabetic nephropathy, which is characterized by intrinsic renal injury. This patient's diabetes is poorly controlled, which puts her at risk of developing diabetic nephropathy. However, the acute onset of symptoms and the association with treatment for disseminated cutaneous herpes zoster, make a different diagnosis more likely.

B) INCORRECT:

Anti-GBM antibody formation and deposition is the underlying mechanism of Goodpasture disease, which can manifest with a BUN:creatinine ratio indicating intrinsic renal failure, as seen in this case. However, subsequent damage of the glomerular basement membrane and capillary wall causes nephritic syndrome, which is characterized by impaired glomerular filtration leading to a nephritic urine sediment and salt retention. This results in hypertension and edema, which is not seen in this patient. Pulmonary symptoms (e.g., hemoptysis, cough, dyspnea) would also occur in the majority of patients.

C) INCORRECT:

Coagulative necrosis of the renal papilla (i.e., renal papillary necrosis) has multiple causes, including acute pyelonephritis, urinary tract obstruction, NSAIDs, and diabetes mellitus. Although this patient has diabetes, and renal papillary necrosis can manifest with flank pain and AKI, her exposure to acyclovir and subsequent symptom onset suggest crystal-induced AKI.

D) INCORRECT:

A type IV hypersensitivity reaction is the underlying mechanism of allergic interstitial nephritis. This condition is most commonly triggered by drugs (e.g., antibiotics, NSAIDs, PPIs) and can manifest with flank pain, fever, arthralgia, a diffuse, maculopapular, itchy rash, and a BUN:creatinine ratio that indicates intrinsic renal damage. However, this patient's skin findings are related to disseminated cutaneous herpes zoster and described as healing; they also occurred before the medication was administered. Furthermore, AIN usually occurs ≥ 3 days to weeks after exposure to the offending agent.

E) INCORRECT:

Ureteropelvic junction obstruction can be either acquired or congenital, and while patients with this form of obstruction are prone to hydronephrosis and/or recurrent pyelonephritis that can also manifest with colicky flank pain, this condition typically manifests earlier in life. Furthermore, urinary obstruction would show a BUN:creatinine ratio of > 10–20:1, indicating post-renal failure. The acute onset of this patient's renal injury and bilateral flank pain soon after initiation of treatment for disseminated cutaneous herpes zoster suggests a different diagnosis.

F) INCORRECT:

A decrease in renal plasma flow can be seen in prerenal kidney injury (e.g., due to volume depletion or hypotension), which is the most common cause of AKI in hospitalized patients. However, prerenal AKI is characterized by a BUN:creatinine ratio ≥ 20:1, while this patient's ratio is < 10:1. Furthermore, this patient shows no evidence of the most common causes of prerenal kidney injury (she does not have tachycardia or hypotension).

G) INCORRECT:

Immune complex deposition in glomeruli with subsequent damage to the glomerular basement membrane is the underlying mechanism of immune complex glomerulonephritis (e.g., IgA nephropathy, membranoproliferative nephropathy), which can also manifest with a BUN:creatinine ratio indicating intrinsic renal damage. However, damage to the glomerular filtration barrier results in protein loss and, consequently, symptoms of nephrotic syndrome such as marked edema and frothy urine. Moreover, nephrotic syndrome does not manifest with bilateral flank pain and is not a common side effect of antiviral drugs.

H) CORRECT:

Tubular obstruction due to crystals is the underlying mechanism of crystal-induced AKI. Acyclovir has a low urine solubility and can precipitate within the renal tubules, causing tubular toxicity and obstruction. AKI is more likely to occur secondary to IV bolus injections of acyclovir but can also occur after oral intake, particularly in patients with volume depletion or preexisting renal conditions (e.g., diabetic nephropathy). Urinalysis in this patient would likely reveal hematuria, pyuria, and crystalluria. Adequate volume repletion before and during the administration of acyclovir is effective in preventing crystal-induced AKI.

Other frequent causes of crystal-induced AKI include ethylene glycol, protease inhibitors (especially indinavir and atazanavir), methotrexate, sulfonamides, or high doses of vitamin C. The offending agent should be discontinued and IV fluids administered to improve excretion and prevent further obstruction of the tubules. Crystal-induced AKI generally has a good prognosis.
questions.hint: This patient has disseminated cutaneous herpes zoster and is likely undergoing treatment with intravenous acyclovir. She now presents with bilateral, colicky flank pain associated with a marked increase in BUN and creatinine and a BUN:creatinine ratio < 10:1, which is characteristic of intrinsic renal damage and acute kidney injury (AKI).

questions.text:
A 67-year-old man comes to the emergency department for the evaluation of two episodes of red urine since this morning. He has no pain with urination. He reports lower back pain and fever. Six months ago, he was diagnosed with osteoarthritis of the right knee that he manages with 1–2 tablets of ibuprofen per day. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the past 45 years. He does not drink alcohol. His temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), pulse is 95/min, and blood pressure is 130/80 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a faint, diffuse maculopapular rash, and bilateral flank pain. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Urinalysis shows:


Blood
+3


Protein
+1


RBC
10–12/hpf


RBC cast
negative


Eosinophils
numerous


Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The onset of this patient's signs and symptoms (eosinophiluria, gross hematuria, flank pain, and rash) six months after starting treatment with ibuprofen suggests allergic interstitial nephritis, a form of acute tubulointerstitial nephritis. This condition is typically caused by a hypersensitivity reaction to drugs, especially NSAIDs, antibiotics, PPIs, and diuretics. The onset of symptoms is variable (ranging from days to months following the exposure) and usually does not depend on the drug dose. The first step in management of this patient should be discontinuation of ibuprofen and administration of IV fluids.

B) INCORRECT:

While acute pyelonephritis can also manifest with fever, flank pain, and, in rare cases, eosinophiluria, this patient's use of an NSAID and the presence of a rash suggest a different diagnosis.

C) INCORRECT:

Glomerulonephritis is characterized by injury and inflammation of the glomeruli that can be caused by various conditions. Patients with acute glomerulonephritis commonly present with nephritic syndrome or nephrotic syndrome. This patient's clinical and laboratory findings are typical of a hypersensitivity reaction which is caused by ibuprofen.

D) INCORRECT:

Drugs with low urine solubility (e.g., acyclovir, indinavir, ciprofloxacin, and methotrexate) precipitate within the renal tubules and can thus cause tubular obstruction leading to crystal-induced acute kidney injury (AKI). Urinalysis in patients with crystal-induced AKI often shows hematuria, pyuria, and crystals on brightfield microscopy. However, individuals with crystal-induced AKI are usually asymptomatic. In many cases, only elevation of serum creatinine leads to detection of the kidney injury.

E) INCORRECT:

Renal cell carcinoma (RCC) is the most common cause of renal malignancy in adults and characteristically manifests with painless gross hematuria. Although this patient's age and positive smoking history put him at increased risk for RCC, this condition would not explain this patient's eosinophiluria and rash.

F) INCORRECT:

Henoch-Schönlein purpura (HSP) is a type of small vessel vasculitis that manifests with a skin rash with palpable purpura in almost all patients. However, this condition most commonly occurs in children (with 90% of the cases reported in children < 10 years of age), and about 50% of individuals with HSP present with features of nephritic syndrome (e.g., edema, oliguria and hypertension), which this patient does not have.

G) INCORRECT:

Acute tubular necrosis (ATN) is either caused by ischemia/hypoxia (e.g. due to hypotension) or nephrotoxicity (e.g., due to certain drugs, including NSAIDs). ATN usually manifests with clinical features of acute kidney injury (1. oliguric or anuric phase, 2. polyuric phase, 3. recovery phase). It would not explain the patient's rash and fever. ATN is the principal cause of acute kidney injury in hospitalized patients.
questions.hint: This patient presents with gross hematuria, fever, flank pain, rash, and eosinophiluria. These features are consistent with a specific kidney disease that is most commonly caused by drugs that act as haptens (particularly antibiotics and NSAIDs), inducing a hypersensitivity reaction.

questions.text:
A 56-year-old African-American man comes to the physician for intermittent episodes of dark urine and mild flank pain. The patient has had three episodes of frank reddish discoloration of his urine within 1 month. He has chronic headaches and back pain for which he has been taking aspirin and ibuprofen daily for 1 year. The patient has sickle cell trait. He has smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for 10 years. He appears well. His temperature is 37.4°C (99.3°F). His pulse is 66/min, and his blood pressure is 150/90 mm Hg. Physical exam shows mild, bilateral flank tenderness. Laboratory analysis shows a serum creatinine concentration of 2.4 mg/dL. Urine studies are shown below.


Urine



Blood
3+


Protein
2+


RBC
> 10/hpf


WBC
3/hpf


Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's hematuria?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH) can cause episodes of red-colored urine due to renal hemoglobin filtration. However, the clinical presentation is typically dominated by nonspecific symptoms of hemolytic anemia, including fatigue and jaundice, which are absent in this patient. More importantly, this patient's laboratory results show RBCs in the urine while the red-colored urine of PNH results from free hemoglobin in the urine.

B) INCORRECT:

Purulent renal inflammation is characteristic for pyelonephritis, which can sometimes manifest with hematuria, particularly if there is concurrent cystitis. Flank pain is another common finding, although it is more commonly unilateral. Furthermore, pyelonephritis is more common in women and typically manifests with additional symptoms such as fever, chills, nausea, and vomiting, as well as symptoms of lower urinary tract infection, including urinary frequency, urinary urgency, dysuria, and suprapubic pain, which are absent in this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

Renal reperfusion injury is characteristic for ischemic acute tubular necrosis (ATN), which can occur secondary to prolonged hypotension in the setting of trauma, surgery, sepsis, and kidney transplantation. While sickle cell trait (SCT) is associated with sickling in times of severe oxygen deficiency, which can result in microthrombotic infarctions in the kidney, it is unclear to what extent SCT increases the risk of ATN. Regardless, patients with ATN present with signs of acute renal injury (e.g., anuria, elevated BUN and creatinine), while this patient presents with hematuria and flank pain and is otherwise clinically well. Furthermore, this patient has no history of severe hypotension or oxygen deficiency (e.g., extreme dehydration, physical stress), making this diagnosis unlikely.

D) CORRECT:

Ischemia of the renal papillae can lead to renal papillary necrosis. The etiology is often multifactorial; chronic NSAID use, as seen in this patient, can result in analgesic nephropathy due to prolonged reduction in renal blood flow causing papillary ischemia and a decline in GFR. Sickle cell trait is another risk factor for renal papillary necrosis; transient sickling of RBCs in the renal capillaries results in microthrombotic infarctions and sloughing of necrotic papillae. The onset of renal papillary necrosis can be acute or chronic. Acute cases can manifest with gross hematuria and flank pain, as in this patient, while chronic cases are typically asymptomatic or have only mild symptoms.

Chronic NSAID use also has gastrointestinal (GI) adverse effects (e.g., bleeding and peptic ulcer disease) and increases the risk of cardiovascular events, including myocardial infarction, heart failure, stroke, and death.

E) INCORRECT:

Vaso-occlusive crises occur in patients with sickle cell disease (SCD) and can manifest with hematuria and flank pain if the renal vasculature is involved. However, this patient has sickle cell trait (SCT), a condition in which vaso-occlusive crises are seldomly seen. While SCT has likely contributed to this patient's painless hematuria and flank pain, his symptoms are not caused by vaso-occlusive crisis.

Most patients with SCT are asymptomatic and features of SCD very rarely occur as a result of oxygen deficiency. This subset of patients typically has a concurrent inherited hemoglobinopathy.

F) INCORRECT:

Some analgesics cause direct nephrotoxic injury to the kidney, which can manifest with hematuria, flank pain, and elevated creatinine levels. In particular, the banned analgesic phenacetin causes direct nephrotoxic injury via lipid peroxidation within tubular cells. However, this patient takes daily aspirin and ibuprofen. While NSAIDs are also considered nephrotoxic, they are primarily associated with indirect kidney damage due to suppression of prostaglandin production, which results in reduced renal blood flow.
questions.hint: This patient's history of chronic analgesic use to manage his back pain and headaches in conjunction with his sickle cell trait put him at significant risk of developing this renal pathology!

questions.text:
A hospitalized 45-year-old man has had mild flank pain since awakening 3 hours ago. He also reports a new generalized rash. Two weeks ago, he was diagnosed with pulmonary tuberculosis. Current medications include isoniazid, pyrazinamide, rifampin, ethambutol, and pyridoxine. His temperature is 38.3°C (100.9°F), pulse is 74/min, and blood pressure is 128/72 mm Hg. Examination of the skin shows diffuse erythema with confluent papules. There is no costovertebral angle tenderness. Laboratory studies show:


Leukocyte count
9,800/mm3



Segmented neutrophils
59%


Bands
3%


Eosinophils
4%


Lymphocytes
29%


Monocytes
5%


Serum



Urea nitrogen
25 mg/dL


Creatinine
1.9 mg/dL


Urine



WBC
8–10/hpf


Eosinophils
numerous


RBC
5–6/hpf


RBC casts
negative


WBC casts
numerous


In addition to intravenous fluid resuscitation, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Increase the dose of antituberculosis drugs

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Hemodialysis might be necessary in a case of severe or prolonged allergic interstitial nephritis in order to replace renal function. For better evaluation, further lab studies should be obtained, e.g., potassium levels and electrolytes. However, elevated BUN and creatinine levels alone are never an absolute indication for initiation of hemodialysis and this patient can still benefit from much less invasive therapeutic measures. He does not meet any indications for hemodialysis (yet).

B) INCORRECT:

Ciprofloxacin is a first-line treatment for acute pyelonephritis, which commonly causes fever, flank pain, and pyuria. However, patients with pyelonephritis are usually acutely ill and present with chills, nausea, and costovertebral angle tenderness on examination. In the setting of an acute bacterial infection, moreover, leukocytosis with a left shift would also be expected. Furthermore, a maculopapular rash, eosinophilia, and eosinophiluria are not features of pyelonephritis.

C) INCORRECT:

Renal tuberculosis (TB) is a form of extrapulmonary tuberculosis most commonly seen in individuals with cellular immunity deficiency (e.g., patients with AIDS), in which case Mycobacterium tuberculosis does not remain confined to the lungs. Although this patient has flank pain, microscopic hematuria, and fever, the findings of eosinophiluria and a maculopapular rash are more consistent with acute (allergic) interstitial nephritis, and increasing the dose of anti-TB drugs may worsen this patient's condition.

D) CORRECT:

Allergic interstitial nephritis is an intrinsic renal cause of acute kidney injury that is caused by a drug hypersensitivity reaction. Given that this patient recently began treatment for active tuberculosis, the most likely cause is rifampin. Initial treatment involves addressing the underlying cause (i.e., discontinuation of the offending drug) and providing IV fluids, as the condition will usually resolve spontaneously after discontinuation of the causal agent.

Allergic interstitial nephritis is most commonly caused by antibiotics (cephalosporins, penicillins, sulfonamides), NSAIDs, rifampin, phenytoin, or allopurinol.

E) INCORRECT:

Percutaneous nephrostomy tube drainage may be appropriate for the treatment of acute upper urinary tract obstruction, which commonly manifests with flank pain. While azotemia and acute kidney injury can be caused by postrenal obstruction, image studies (e.g., renal ultrasound) are needed first in order to establish a diagnosis. Furthermore, this patient's findings of fever, rash, and eosinophiluria are more consistent with acute interstitial nephritis.

F) INCORRECT:

Serum protein electrophoresis would be the best initial test for a patient with suspected multiple myeloma (MM). While intrinsic renal injury and elevated BUN and creatinine may be a complication of immunoglobulins accumulating in the renal tubule (i.e., Bence Jones protein), MM most commonly manifests in elderly patients with bone pain and hypercalcemia. Microscopic hematuria, fever, the findings of eosinophiluria and a maculopapular rash would not be expected in a patient with MM.
Image Description:

Deviations of the individual protein fractions from the normal finding (for comparison, upper left) are shown in red.

G) INCORRECT:

Renal biopsy would be an appropriate diagnostic step in the context of acute kidney injury if glomerular injury were suspected as the cause of hematuria, such as in rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis. Although this patient has flank pain and RBCs on urinalysis, he does not have RBC casts, and his fever, rash, and eosinophiluria are more consistent with acute (allergic) interstitial nephritis. While renal biopsy would be the most accurate diagnostic test for acute interstitial nephritis, it is not necessary and would delay a more appropriate initial step in management.

H) INCORRECT:

Furosemide alleviates symptoms of volume overload (i.e., dyspnea) and would be an appropriate treatment for some causes of acute kidney injury, e.g., prerenal azotemia in a patient with congestive heart failure. The ratio between this patient's elevated BUN and creatinine is < 20:1, making prerenal causes unlikely. This patient does not present with any signs or symptoms of volume overload, e.g., peripheral edema or jugular venous distention. Also, the findings of fever, maculopapular rash, and eosinophiluria are more consistent with acute interstitial nephritis.
questions.hint: This patient presents with flank pain, diffuse maculopapular rash, and fever 2 weeks after the initiation of antituberculosis treatment. In combination with eosinophilia, hematuria, pyuria, and eosinophiluria on laboratory studies, these features suggest allergic interstitial nephritis.

questions.text: A 48-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 2-day history of fever, flank pain, and hematuria. He has chronic back pain, for which he has been taking meloxicam for the past 2 weeks. His temperature is 38.9°C (102°F). Physical examination shows a diffuse maculopapular rash over his trunk and extremities. Urinalysis shows 10–15 RBC/hpf, 20 WBC/hpf, and numerous eosinophils. Microscopic examination of a kidney biopsy specimen is most likely to show which of the following findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Tubular crystal precipitation is seen in crystal-induced AKI. It is caused by low-solubility drugs (e.g., acyclovir, indinavir, ciprofloxacin, methotrexate) that precipitate in the renal tubule, causing obstruction of normal urine flow and damage to renal tubular cells. Although asymptomatic in most patients, crystal-induced AKI can sometimes manifest with flank pain and acute onset of hematuria, as seen here. However, this patient's meloxicam use (not a low-solubility drug), eosinophiluria, and rash are inconsistent with crystal-induced AKI.

B) INCORRECT:

Deposition of IgA in the mesangium is consistent with IgA nephropathy. Clinical features include hematuria, pyuria, flank pain, and low-grade fever, as seen in this patient. However, IgA nephropathy is most commonly preceded by a respiratory or gastrointestinal infection. In addition, IgA nephropathy is not associated with a maculopapular rash or eosinophiluria.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of kidney tissue (PAS stain)

A glomerulus surrounded by numerous tubules is visible in the center of each image. There is a proliferation of mesangial cells (examples marked by yellow circles) with extracellular matrix deposition within the glomeruli. In IgA nephropathy, these changes can range from focal segmental (examples indicated by black arrows) to diffuse (examples indicated by yellow arrow-heads).

This is the characteristic histopathologic appearance of IgA nephropathy.

Blue outlines: Glomerular capillaries

C) INCORRECT:

Glomerular crescent formation is a feature of rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (RPGN), which can present with acute onset of hematuria, pyuria, and flank pain, as seen in this patient. However, it is also associated with anuria, edema, and acanthocytes and RBC casts on urinalysis. In addition, RPGN is inconsistent with this patient's maculopapular rash or eosinophiluria.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of kidney biopsy tissue (H&E stain; high magnification)

A hypercellular, crescent-shaped zone with an inflammatory infiltrate (yellow overlay) is visible within the glomerulus.

Glomerular crescent formation is a characteristic histological finding in RPGN.

D) INCORRECT:

Tubular cells with clear cytoplasm are seen in clear cell carcinoma, the most common type of renal cell carcinoma (RCC). RCC can also present with fever, painless hematuria, and flank pain. However, RCC is inconsistent with the maculopapular rash, pyuria, and eosinophiluria seen in this patient. Furthermore, this patient lacks additional characteristic findings of RCC, such as hypertension, weight loss, fatigue, night sweats, and a palpable abdominal mass.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a biopsy specimen (H&E stain; high magnification)

Countless nests of polygonal cells (examples indicated by green overlays) with clear cytoplasm, filled with lipids and glycogen, are visible (examples indicated by yellow overlays). The tissue is richly vascularized (examples of blood vessels indicated by arrowheads).

This is the typical histopathological appearance of clear cell renal cell carcinoma.

E) CORRECT:

Diffuse interstitial T-cell and monocyte infiltration is seen in allergic interstitial nephritis (AIN), a hypersensitivity reaction that can occur days to weeks after the initiation of NSAIDs, such as meloxicam. Drugs that act as haptens (e.g., NSAIDs, antibiotics) have the ability to elicit an uncontrolled immune response and acute kidney injury.

F) INCORRECT:

Renal papillary necrosis is characteristic of analgesic nephropathy (e.g., prolonged use of NSAIDs and/or acetaminophen). Although analgesic nephropathy can also present with hematuria and flank pain, it is usually due to chronic analgesic use. This patient's maculopapular rash and eosinophiluria are inconsistent with papillary necrosis.

Other causes of renal papillary necrosis include sickle cell disease, pyelonephritis, and diabetes mellitus.

G) INCORRECT:

Cortical and medullary cyst formation is seen in autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD). It results from a mutation in the PKD-1 gene, on chromosome 16, which encodes for polycystin. This patient's age, flank pain (caused by cyst rupture or UTI), and pyuria raise concern for ADPKD. However, ADPKD is associated with chronic renal failure, hypertension, and recurrent urinary tract infections. In addition, ADPKD is inconsistent with this patient's maculopapular rash or eosinophiluria.
questions.hint: This patient's presentation (2-day fever, flank pain, maculopapular rash) and urine abnormalities (hematuria, sterile pyuria, eosinophiluria) are consistent with a hypersensitivity reaction, most likely due to his NSAID intake (meloxicam).

questions.text: A 60-year-old man comes to the physician because of flank pain, rash, and blood-tinged urine for 1 day. Two months ago, he was started on hydrochlorothiazide for hypertension. He takes acetaminophen for back pain. Examination shows a generalized, diffuse maculopapular rash. Serum studies show a creatinine concentration of 3.0 mg/dL. Renal ultrasonography shows no abnormalities. Which of the following findings is most likely to be observed in this patient?

choices.text: Dermal IgA deposition on skin biopsy
Mesangial IgA deposits on renal biopsy

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Urinary crystals on Brightfield microscopy are typical in patients with crystal-induced acute kidney injury (AKI). Drugs with low urine solubility (e.g., acyclovir, indinavir, ciprofloxacin, and methotrexate) precipitate in the renal tubules and can cause tubular obstruction leading to crystal-induced AKI. Crystal-induced AKI is often detected by increased creatinine levels, and some cases may manifest with hematuria and flank pain, as seen in this patient. However, most individuals with crystal-induced AKI are asymptomatic, and this patient lacks a history of taking drugs associated with the condition.

B) INCORRECT:

Dermal IgA deposition on skin biopsy is a finding typical in patients with Henoch-Schönlein purpura (HSP), a type of small-vessel vasculitis that manifests as a skin rash with palpable purpura in almost all patients. However, 90% of cases occur in children < 10 years old, and about half of individuals with HSP present with features of nephritic syndrome (e.g., edema and oliguria), which this patient does not have.

C) INCORRECT:

Crescent-shape extracapillary cell proliferation is a finding typical in patients with rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (RPGN). This patient has some features of RPGN, including gross hematuria, flank pain, and a marked increase in creatinine (often > 3 mg/dL). However, RPGN typically presents with elevated inflammatory markers (e.g., leukocytosis) and decreased urine output or anuria, which are not seen in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

Papillary calcifications on CT imaging are a finding typical in patients with analgesic nephropathy. This patient has a history of taking acetaminophen, which is associated with analgesic nephropathy. He also presents with some clinical findings of analgesic nephropathy, including hematuria and elevated creatinine levels. However, renal sonography of patients with analgesic nephropathy typically shows shrunken kidneys and papillary calcifications, which is not the case here. Moreover, his other signs, including flank pain and diffuse maculopapular rash, in conjunction with a history of taking a thiazide diuretic, make a different finding more likely.

E) INCORRECT:

Mesangial IgA deposits on renal biopsy are a characteristic finding in patients with IgA nephropathy (Berger disease). This patient has some features of IgA nephropathy, including gross hematuria and flank pain. However, IgA nephropathy mostly occurs in patients 20–30 years of age and is usually triggered by upper respiratory tract or gastrointestinal infections. Moreover, this patient lacks other findings typical of IgA nephropathy such as low-grade fever.

F) CORRECT:

Eosinophiluria is a typical finding in patients with allergic interstitial nephritis, a form of acute tubulointerstitial nephritis. This condition is typically caused by a hypersensitivity reaction to drugs, especially PPIs, NSAIDs, antibiotics, and diuretics. The onset of symptoms is variable (commonly 2–3 months following the exposure) and usually does not depend on the drug dose. The first step in managing this patient should be discontinuation of his thiazide diuretic and administration of IV fluids.
questions.hint: The occurrence of acute kidney injury and a generalized rash 2 months after the initiation of a thiazide diuretic suggests the diagnosis of allergic interstitial nephritis.

questions.text: A 75-year-old man comes to the physician because of fatigue and decreased urine output for 1 week. He takes ibuprofen as needed for lower back pain and docusate for constipation. Physical examination shows tenderness to palpation over the lumbar spine. There is pedal edema. Laboratory studies show a hemoglobin concentration of 8.7 g/dL, a serum creatinine concentration of 2.3 mg/dL, and a serum calcium concentration of 12.6 mg/dL. Urine dipstick is negative for blood and protein. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Antiglomerular basement membrane antibodies (anti-GBM antibodies) suggest Goodpasture syndrome, which can also cause fatigue and renal failure with edema, as seen in this patient. However, this patient lacks signs of pulmonary involvement (e.g., hemoptysis, cough) and renal failure is typically rapidly progressive with proteinuria and hematuria. The bone pain and constipation in this patient are better explained by another cause.

B) CORRECT:

Precipitation of excessive nephrotoxic immunoglobulin light chains (Bence Jones proteins) is the underlying cause of myeloma cast nephropathy and the most common form of acute or subacute kidney injury in patients with multiple myeloma (MM). The light chains cause eosinophilic intratubular cast formation and obstruction. They have a direct toxic effect on the renal tubular epithelial cells, resulting in tubular atrophy. A dipstick urine test cannot detect light chain proteins in the urine since it is specific for albumin.

Besides myeloma cast nephropathy, renal disease in MM patients may be due to various other mechanisms, including AL amyloidosis (usually presenting with nephrotic syndrome due to glomerular dysfunction) or hypercalcemia (causing nephrocalcinosis).

C) INCORRECT:

Renal deposition of AL amyloid suggests a renal manifestation of AL amyloidosis, which may occur in patients with multiple myeloma. However, AL amyloidosis typically affects multiple organ systems, such as the kidneys (nephrotic syndrome with proteinuria and orthostatic hypotension), heart (restrictive cardiomyopathy, atrioventricular block), and gastrointestinal tract (malabsorption syndromes). This patient has no cardiac abnormalities and urinalysis was negative for proteins.

D) INCORRECT:

Anti-dsDNA antibodies are typically found in systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). By cross-reacting with the glomerular basement membrane, they promote an inflammatory response, which may result in lupus nephritis. This patient's renal failure, lower back pain (possibly due to arthritis), and fatigue do support this diagnosis. However, he lacks other classic findings of underlying SLE, e.g., fever, cardiac abnormalities, and/or a malar rash. Lastly, hematuria and proteinuria are common in lupus nephritis but are not present here.

E) INCORRECT:

Hypersensitivity reaction is the underlying pathomechanism of allergic interstitial nephritis, which may occur in patients with long-term use of analgesic agents, including ibuprofen. However, it usually causes acute inflammation with fever, colicky flank pain (due to papillary necrosis), and/or hematuria, none of which is present in this patient.
questions.hint: This elderly patient presents with features of renal failure including oliguria, peripheral edema (indicating fluid overload), and elevated serum creatinine. His history of fatigue, persistent bone pain, and constipation (which could be due to hypercalcemia), together with the findings of anemia and hypercalcemia, make multiple myeloma the most likely underlying cause.

questions.text:
A 58-year-old female comes to the physician because of generalized fatigue and malaise for 3 months. Four months ago, she was treated for a urinary tract infection with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. She has hypertension, asthma, chronic lower back pain, and chronic headaches. Current medications include hydrochlorothiazide, an albuterol inhaler, naproxen, and an aspirin-caffeine combination. Examination shows conjunctival pallor. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
8.9 g/dL


Serum



 Urea nitrogen
46 mg/dL


 Creatinine
2.4 mg/dL


 Calcium
9.8 mg/dL


Urine



 Protein
1+


 Blood
1+


 RBCs
none


 WBCs
9-10/hpf


Urine cultures are negative. Ultrasound shows shrunken kidneys with irregular contours and papillary calcifications. Which of the following is the most likely underlying mechanism of this patient's renal failure?

choices.text: Precipitation of drugs within the renal tubules

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Overproduction of light chains is most frequently associated with multiple myeloma and systemic amyloidosis, both of which can cause chronic kidney disease (CKD). Patients with multiple myeloma present with pain related to skeletal involvement of the disease, anemia, and elevated serum calcium. This patient has normal serum calcium levels, which makes multiple myeloma unlikely. The chronic lower back pain in this patient is of too long a course for it to be attributable to multiple myeloma, and her anemia is likely due to underlying kidney disease.

In addition to renal disease, systemic amyloidosis presents with involvement of multiple organ systems, including the cardiovascular system (cardiomyopathy), skin (waxy skin and easy bruising), hepatic system (hepatomegaly), and nervous system (peripheral neuropathy). This patient does not show involvement of any of these organ systems. Additionally, the kidney disease associated with systemic amyloidosis usually presents with more severe proteinuria than that seen in this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

A hypersensitivity reaction to NSAIDs or a sulfonamide antibiotic, such as TMP/SMX, can cause AKI in the form of tubulointerstitial nephritis, which would present as a rapid decompensation in kidney function. Potential signs include fever, rash, and eosinophilia. This patient does not have any of these signs and her 3-month history of fatigue suggests a more chronic disease course.

C) CORRECT:

Prostaglandin I2 (i.e., prostacyclin) enhances renal blood flow by dilating renal capillaries, most prominently in the medulla of the kidney. Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) inhibit prostaglandin production, resulting in decreased renal blood flow. After prolonged exposure to analgesics, especially analgesics used in combination (naproxen and aspirin), as is the case here, patients develop renal papillary necrosis and subsequent analgesic nephropathy (chronic kidney disease).

D) INCORRECT:

Infection with an acid-fast bacillus such as M. tuberculosis can cause renal damage and subsequent chronic kidney disease. However, this patient does not have risk factors for tuberculosis (e.g., travel to areas where the disease is endemic, HIV, time spent in prison) or symptoms suggestive of the disease (e.g., hemoptysis, night sweats, weight loss).

E) INCORRECT:

Drugs such as acyclovir, indinavir, methotrexate, and ciprofloxacin are poorly soluble in urine and can cause renal tubule obstruction due to drug precipitation, building up as crystals that cause AKI within days to a week. This patient has not been exposed to any drugs that commonly cause crystal-induced AKI and has been symptomatic for 2 months.
questions.hint: This woman has features of kidney dysfunction: fatigue, anemia, uremia, and elevated creatinine. She also has sterile pyuria (WBCs in the urine with negative cultures) and ultrasonography shows changes associated with chronic kidney disease. Along with these findings, her long-term use of naproxen and the aspirin-caffeine combination makes analgesic nephropathy the most likely diagnosis.

questions.text:
A 48-year-old woman with chronic tension headaches comes to the physician because of several episodes of bilateral flank pain and reddish urine within the past month. Current medications include aspirin, which she takes almost daily for headaches. Her temperature is 37.4°C (99.3°F) and her blood pressure is 150/90 mm Hg. Physical examination shows costovertebral tenderness to percussion bilaterally. Laboratory studies show a hemoglobin concentration of 10.2 g/dL and serum creatinine concentration of 2.4 mg/dL. Urine studies show:


Urine



Protein
3+


RBC
> 16/hpf


WBC
2/hpf


There are no casts or dysmorphic RBCs visualized on microscopic analysis of the urine. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's hematuria?

choices.text: Tubular lumen obstruction by protein casts
Necrotizing inflammation of the renal glomeruli
Bacterial infection of the renal parenchyma

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Obstruction of the renal tubular lumen by protein casts can be seen in multiple myeloma or after administration of radiocontrast agents. Although those conditions can lead to acute kidney injury, this patient's medical history suggests a different cause. Moreover, although microscopic hematuria can be seen in light chain cast nephropathy, gross hematuria as with this patient is rarely seen.

B) INCORRECT:

Necrotizing inflammation of the renal glomeruli is characteristic of glomerulonephritis secondary to granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA). While GPA can manifest with bilateral flank pain and gross hematuria, urinalysis would reveal RBC casts with dysmorphic RBCs. Furthermore, this patient does not have any other symptoms of GPA such as pulmonary or nasopharyngeal involvement.

C) INCORRECT:

Bacterial infection of the renal parenchyma describes pyelonephritis, which can cause costovertebral angle tenderness, acute kidney injury, and hematuria similar to this patient. However, pyelonephritis typically manifests with acute, unilateral pain, and accompanied by fever and pyuria. The absence of fever and significant pyuria makes this cause unlikely.

D) INCORRECT:

Lipid peroxidation is a form of free radical damage that can occur in renal tubular cells due to phenacetin or acetaminophen (the metabolite of phenacetin) use. Phenacetin, an NSAID that is no longer used, is thought to cause direct nephrotoxicity through this mechanism, resulting in renal papillary necrosis and acute kidney injury, similar to this patient. However, modern NSAIDs do not cause lipid peroxidation.

E) CORRECT:

NSAIDs suppress the production of vasodilatory prostaglandins, thereby inhibiting vasodilation of the vasa recta and decreasing blood flow to highly sensitive renal papillae. This leads to ischemia and eventual sloughing of the necrotic renal papillae, which may manifest clinically without any symptoms, or with hematuria, as seen here. Other causes of renal papillary necrosis include sickle cell disease, acute pyelonephritis, and diabetes mellitus.
questions.hint: This woman's presentation and history of analgesic use as well as the urine studies are consistent with renal papillary necrosis, which can present with flank pain and hematuria.

questions.text: A 76-year-old woman is evaluated for nausea and flank pain 2 days after admission to the hospital for treatment of disseminated herpes zoster. She has type 2 diabetes mellitus poorly controlled with insulin. She has been receiving intravenous antiviral treatment since admission. Temperature is 36.9°C (98.4°F). Examination shows multiple groups of vesicles on her trunk. Her serum creatinine concentration is 3.2 mg/dL; on admission, creatinine concentration was 1.1 mg/dL. This patient's findings are most likely caused by which of the following mechanisms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Ascending bacterial infection of the urinary tract leads to pyelonephritis. Patients with pyelonephritis typically present with flank pain and can also have nausea. Additionally, patients with diabetes are at increased risk of infection. This patient, however, does not have systemic symptoms, such as fever and chills, or other typical symptoms of pyelonephritis (e.g., dysuria, increased urinary frequency and urgency, costovertebral angle tenderness).

B) INCORRECT:

A type IV hypersensitivity reaction is consistent with acute allergic interstitial nephritis (AIN), which most commonly results from medication use, and this patient's AKI and flank pain began after starting a new medication. However, AIN is associated with antibiotics (e.g., penicillins, cephalosporins, rifampin, sulfonamides, and quinolones), NSAIDs, proton pump inhibitors, and diuretics; this patient is taking an antiviral drug, which leads to nephrotoxicity via a different mechanism. Furthermore, in addition to flank pain, AIN typically manifests with fever, rash, hematuria, and pyuria (classically eosinophilia).

C) INCORRECT:

Glycation of the basement membrane is the mechanism of diabetic nephropathy. This patient's condition, however, is acute and associated with starting a new medication whereas diabetic nephropathy is usually chronic and progressive.

D) INCORRECT:

Papillary necrosis can occur as a result of NSAID use. Inhibition of prostacyclin synthesis causes vasoconstriction of the medullary blood vessels, resulting in coagulative necrosis of the renal medullary pyramids and papillae. This patient does not have a history of NSAID use; instead, she has a history of using an antiviral drug, which causes a different renal condition. Other causes of renal papillary necrosis include pyelonephritis, obstructive uropathy, sickle cell disease, tuberculosis, chronic liver disease, and renal transplant rejection.

E) CORRECT:

Crystalline nephropathy occurs when drugs with low urine solubility (e.g., acyclovir, methotrexate, ciprofloxacin, indinavir) form crystals that are deposited inside renal tubules, causing obstruction that leads to AKI. This patient's rapidly increasing creatinine levels following the administration of an antiviral drug (likely acyclovir) are consistent with crystal-induced AKI. Serum studies typically show a BUN:creatinine ratio < 15:1. Patients are usually asymptomatic but may present with nausea and flank pain. Diagnosis of crystalline nephropathy is made using brightfield microscopy to visualize crystals. Treatment consists of discontinuation of the triggering agent and hydration with IV fluids.
questions.hint: Volume repletion before and during the administration of antiviral drugs, such as acyclovir, could have prevented this patient's acute kidney injury (AKI).

questions.text:
A 20-year-old male college student presents for evaluation of a rash that developed gradually during the past 3 days. Two weeks ago, he began a 10-day course of amoxicillin for streptococcal pharyngitis. He takes no other medications. His medical history is unremarkable. A paternal uncle has Alport syndrome.
His blood pressure is 140/85 mm Hg, his heart rate is 100 beats per minute, and his temperature is 37.5°C. Physical examination reveals a diffuse, erythematous maculopapular rash, predominantly across the trunk.
Laboratory testing yields the following results:



Patient value
Reference range


Hemoglobin (g/dL)
13.5

9600
4500–11,000

The platelet count and leukocyte differential are normal. Urinalysis shows 1+ protein, 1–3 red cells per high-power field (reference range, 0–2),10–20 white cells per high-power field (0–2), and no bacteria.
Renal ultrasonography shows normal-size kidneys without hydronephrosis.
Which one of the following conditions is the most likely explanation for acute kidney injury in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient presents with a rash and acute kidney injury 2 weeks after starting a beta-lactam antibiotic, and he also has sterile pyuria. Taken together, these findings point to acute interstitial nephritis as the most likely diagnosis. Peripheral eosinophilia is seen in only 23% of patients with interstitial nephritis, and the full triad of fever, rash, and peripheral eosinophilia occurs in <10% of patients. In addition, the finding of urinary eosinophils is neither sensitive nor specific for interstitial nephritis; instead, the clinical course or a renal biopsy is most useful for this diagnosis.

Key learning point: Two weeks after initiation of amoxicillin to treat streptococcal pharyngitis, the most likely cause of rash and acute kidney injury in a young man with sterile pyuria is acute interstitial nephritis.

B) INCORRECT:

Postinfectious glomerulonephritis can also manifest 2 weeks or more after a streptococcal infection. At this point, the streptococcal infection has cleared, and glomerulonephritis is a renal-limited process caused by activation of cellular and humoral immunity by nephritogenic strains of group A beta-hemolytic streptococcus. Hypocomplementemia is typically observed. Patients present with hypertension, edema, an active urinary sediment including hematuria, and proteinuria 2 to 3 weeks after the onset of infection. Sometimes, symptoms are mild, and patients will be identified weeks to months later with mild hematuria and proteinuria without altered renal function. Serum complement levels, if depressed, should return to normal within 3 months. Rash and other systemic symptoms are not seen in this disorder.

C) INCORRECT:

Alport syndrome is caused by a mutation in type IV collagen (an important structural component of the glomerular basement membrane) and causes microscopic hematuria, proteinuria, and progressive chronic kidney disease rather than an episode of acute kidney injury. Furthermore, it is most often inherited in an X-linked dominant pattern; therefore, a history of Alport syndrome in a paternal uncle would not be contributory.

D) INCORRECT:

In a patient with immunoglobulin A (IgA) nephropathy, an upper respiratory infection can trigger concurrent gross hematuria and acute kidney injury; these abnormalities are typically seen within 1 to 2 days of the onset of upper respiratory infection symptoms. A rash can be present when IgA nephropathy is part of IgA vasculitis (formerly referred to as Henoch-Schönlein purpura). Complement levels are usually normal.

E) INCORRECT:

Acute tubular necrosis is unlikely without a history of precipitating factors (ischemia or toxins), and the sterile pyuria would be unexpected.

questions.text:
A 40-year-old woman with a history of obesity and type 2 diabetes is seen in the emergency department with symptoms of nausea, vomiting, fatigue, arthralgias, and fever for the past 4 days.
Ten days ago, she presented to the emergency department with a fever and a tender, erythematous area on her right leg. At that time, she was diagnosed with community-acquired methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus cellulitis and began a 14-day course of trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. Her symptoms initially resolved, but then she developed a recurrent fever.
On examination today, she has a heart rate of 87 beats per minute, a blood pressure of 150/80 mm Hg, and a temperature of 38.0°C. There is an erythematous maculopapular rash (figure) over her chest and back, and she has 1+ pitting edema in both lower extremities. The region of cellulitis on her right leg is improved.
Her serum creatinine level is 3.2 mg/dL, compared with 0.9 mg/dL 6 months ago (reference range, 0.6–1.1).

Her urinalysis shows 2+ protein. Urine microscopy shows 0 red cells per high-power field (reference range, 0–2) and 21 to 30 white cells per high-power field (0–2). White-cell casts are present; urine Gram stain is negative for bacteria. A test for urine eosinophils is negative.
What is the most appropriate next step in this case?

choices.text: Perform a urine culture, and replace trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole with ceftriaxone
Measure antinuclear antibody levels, and initiate treatment with methylprednisolone
Measure cold agglutinins and, if positive, initiate plasmapheresis

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A urine culture can be done when pyelonephritis is a consideration. However, pyelonephritis rarely causes acute kidney injury except when the patient develops volume depletion from vomiting or sepsis from the systemic effects of the infection.

B) INCORRECT:

The measurement of an antinuclear antibody can be helpful when systemic lupus erythematosus is considered. Certainly, patients can have a systemic illness with fever and rash, but a maculopapular rash is most consistent with a drug eruption.

C) INCORRECT:

Kidney biopsy is the gold standard for diagnosis, but in some cases, including this one, acute interstitial nephritis (AIN) can be diagnosed on the basis of clinical and laboratory findings without the need for kidney biopsy. Here, the patient recently used a medication that commonly causes AIN, the presentation includes fever and rash, and the urine findings of white cells and white-cell casts are consistent with AIN. The test for urine eosinophils is negative, but this is common in the setting of AIN. Indeed, measuring urine eosinophils has traditionally been considered helpful in the diagnosis of AIN, but the utility of this test is limited by both low sensitivity and low specificity. Furthermore, it is worth noting that interstitial nephritis from some agents may be characterized by a relatively bland urine. If a prolonged course of antibiotics is required, a kidney biopsy may be needed to confirm the diagnosis and guide therapy.

D) CORRECT:

Fever, skin rash, and kidney failure are classic findings seen with acute interstitial nephritis (AIN); peripheral eosinophilia is also often seen. AIN can occur in a wide range of settings, including infections and autoimmune disorders, but medication use accounts for more than 75% of all cases. Antibiotics, proton pump inhibitors, and nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs are commonly implicated.

Key learning point: Three groups of medications that are often implicated in causing acute interstitial nephritis are nonsteroidal antiinflammatory medicines, proton pump inhibitors, and antibiotics.

E) INCORRECT:

Cold agglutinin titers may be elevated in the setting of hemolytic anemia, but this would not explain the patient's rash, and her hemoglobin level is normal.

questions.text:
A 40-year-old man presents to the emergency department with nausea, fever, and arthralgias. Twelve days ago, he was evaluated for epigastric abdominal pain and was diagnosed with Helicobacter pylori infection on the basis of a serologic test. He began a 14-day course of omeprazole, bismuth subsalicylate, tetracycline, and metronidazole, and his epigastric pain gradually improved. The nausea, fever, and arthralgias began 3 days ago. He has no cough, diarrhea, or urinary symptoms.
On examination, he has a heart rate of 87 beats per minute, a blood pressure of 155/90 mm Hg, and a temperature of 38.0°C. The abdomen is nontender. He has an erythematous maculopapular rash over his chest and back and trace edema in both lower extremities.
His serum creatinine level has increased from 0.9 mg/dL 6 months ago to 2.9 mg/dL today (reference range, 0.8–1.3). Other laboratory findings are as follows:
